citation.article-title: Pasteurella haemolytica-like bacterium from a progressive granuloma of cattle in Brazil.

p.s: Description of Pasteurella granulomatis sp. nov.
Pasteurella granulomatis (gran.u.lo'matis. L. dim. n. granulum, a small grain; Gr. suff. -oma, a swelling or tumor; M.L. n. granuloma, a granuloma; M.L. n. granulomatis, of a granuloma)

Three strains of the P. haemolytica-like organism which has been given the name "Pasteurella granulomatis" were isolated from three cattle with typical cases of lechiguana after culture of tissue obtained by deep biopsy of the tumors.
Fourteen isolates were obtained but only three were retained for further study.
Efforts at reproducing the disease with the P. granulomatis isolates were successful and will be described separately.
The purpose of this report is to describe the characteristics of three strains of P. granulomatis and to present evidence that they constitute a new taxon.
All three strains, 26, 115, and 294, appeared as small coccobacilli or short rods after culture on 5% bovine blood agar or Trypticase soy agar for 24 h.
They were indistinguishable in shape from strains of Pasteurella multocida and P. haemolytica.
Of the three strains, only strain 115 had capsules when organisms from colonies on blood agar were stained by Maneval stain (4).
None of the strains was motile.
Although all strains grew on Trypticase soy agar, growth was better on blood agar.
After 24 h on blood agar at 37°C, colonies were round, grayish, and 1 to 2 mm in diameter.
Their appearance resembled that of colonies of P. haemolytica and nonmucoid P. multocida.
After initial isolation, all grew equally well in air or with reduced oxygen partial pressure (10% CO2).
Although the three strains grew anaerobically on blood agar, colonies were smaller.
After incubation for 24 h in broth, the three strains settled to the bottom of the tube, producing a sediment.
All strains grew on MacConkey agar (no. 2; GIBCO Laboratories).
None of the strains caused hemolysis on bovine blood agar of the kind seen with P. haemolytica; however, beta-hemolysis was obtained with the three cultures on sheep blood agar.
The three strains were examined serologically by counter-immunoelectrophoresis (M.
M.
Chengappa, College of Veterinary Medicine, Kansas State University, Manhattan) and slide agglutination (G.
F.
Frank, National Animal Disease Center, Ames, Iowa) to determine if they were known serotypes of P. haemolytica.
Results indicated that they were not serotypes of this species.
Some of the important biochemical characteristics of the three strains are listed below.

The nitrophenyl test was used for the glucosidases, o-nitrophenyl-β-D-galactopyranoside (ONPG), 4-nitrophenyl-β-D-glucopyranosiduronic acid (PGUA), and o-nitrophenyl-β-D-xylopyranoside (PNPX) (3), and the amino acid decarboxylase tests were performed as described previously (3).
Other biochemical tests were performed in three different laboratories by using standard procedures.
Positive reactions were obtained for oxidase, catalase (weak), NO3 reduction, β-glucuronidase (PGUA), and Igalactosidase (ONPG).
Acid but no gas was obtained from glucose, galactose, sucrose, lactose (7 days), maltose (7 days), cellobiose (7 days), sorbitol, mannitol (7 days), salicin, and esculin.
No acid or gas was obtained from arabinose, xylose, rhamnose, mannose, trehalose, melibiose, adonitol, dulcitol, and inositol.

Negative reactions were obtained for indole, NO2 reduction, urease, H2S (triple sugar iron), gelatinase, β-xylosidase (PNPX), phenylalanine deaminase, lysine decarboxylase, arginine decarboxylase and dihydrolase, and ornithine decarboxylase.
Some important characteristics which differentiate P. granulomatis from closely related varieties and species are listed in Table 1.
From the characteristics described, the three strains studied o not conform to the P. haemolytica biotypes described previously (1-3).
Although they resemble "P. haemolytica 3rd type" (3), they differ from this variety in being xylose negative and β-glucuronidase positive.
The three strains of P. granulomatis have been deposited in the collection of W.
Frederiksen at the State Serum Institute, Copenhagen, Denmark, and in the American Type Culture Collection.
The type strain is strain 26.
